description.narrative: Insatsen omfattar stöd till en fond på EBRD - Early Transition Countries Municipal and Environmental Infrastructure. Målet är att minska miljöföroreningar och förbättra naturresursanvändningen, framförallt inom kommunal miljöinfrastuktur.Fonden används för förberedande studier och reformstöd. Under fonden ges stöd till ett flertal projekt, framförallt i Östeuropa.

The overall objective of this project is to promote the sustainable use of natural resources and protection of the environment in the Early Transition Countries. This will be done through the establishment of a Municipal Environmental Infrastructure (MEI) fund that supports the EBRD with resources for consultancy and technical assistance.

description.narrative: EBRD has reported generally on the trust fund as part of the semi-annual progress report covering all of the bilateral Sida-EBRD trust funds in municipal environment infrastructure. A separate report for the municipal solid waste project in the Adjara region in Georgia is also produced as this is being supported by an investment grant as well as consultancy support. The existing results reporting system at EBRD is weak and lacks a systematic way on reporting on results in a useful and cumulative fashion. The progress reporting related to each fund is mainly focusing on on-going projects. Sida is currently engaging in the Bank's efforts to improve donor reporting so that the results of the different projects Sida funds support are reported on. Currently, the Adjara solid waste is the only on-going activity under the fund and there is only about 300 000 EUR left in the fund for new assignments of the total fund agreement amount of about 12 million EUR. For the Adjara project, cooperation has not been working well in the past and during 2016 much effort was spent on sorting out what went wrong as well seeking solutions for a way forward acceptable to all parties. During the semi-annual meeting in November 2016, it was agreed that the EBRD would reinforce the project organisation for the Adjara project by introducing a Financier's Monitoring Consultant to mitigate future implementation risks. In October 2017, the EBRD, with financial support from Sida, engaged the Monitoring Consultant to assist in monitoring implementation of the Loan and the Grant, to ensure that the Project’s construction and operation are carried out according to the implementation, investment and financing plans as well as envisaged standards and applicable laws and regulations. Financiers’ Monitor identified a number of risk factors that have the potential to jeopardise project objectives. The most important one was that the resources and capacity of the Adjara Waste management Company were insufficient and should be improved with the support of Adjara region so that the company can hire expertise needed to be able to implement the project. Following requirements from EBRD, the Ministry of the Adjara republic took action by hiring staff with adequate skill to reinforce the capacity of the solid waste company. The most favourable tender for the construction of the landfill came at a considerable higher price than originally estimated, which was not surprising considering the substantial project delays and the relocation of the landfill site. Sida was therefore requested to give its approval to reallocate its grant funds originally earmarked for closure of existing landfills, to co-finance the new landfill construction contract. Based on reassurances from the EBRD that the Client will increase its loan financing to cover the landfill closure components, Sida could give its approval for the reallocation. In April 2019, the agreement between the contractor and Adjara was signed. EBRD is now working to mobilise technical cooperation funds to hire due diligence consultants and launch technical and financial due diligence for the remaining components, including closure of existing landfills. The EBRD has asked Sida of the possibility to utilize the remaining 300 000 EUR in the fund to finance (part of) such consultancy work. Sida has agreed in principle to this approach, and is now awaiting a formal request from the EBRD, including Terms of Reference and budget, for formal consideration and to give its no-objection or rejection.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
